This patch goes beyond what I thought had happened at last week's meeting in two ways.

1. I think this revision should be closer to Belmiro's original proposal [0], the point of which was basically just that since we're repeating the alphabet, we need additional info to simply the name to determine where a release falls in the complete ordering of releases.  We had been considering dropping the name completely, but instead, we agreed that the Foundation should select the release name.  So now we're back to identifier + name.  (I didn't think we agreed to any changes in tooling, etc., and since we're back to identifier + name, I don't think any such changes are necessary?)

2. While we want to give the naming selection over to the Foundation, I didn't think we were giving them control over the naming criteria (that is, I was expecting that they would continue the alphabetical ordering, 26 chars of ISO basic Latin, maxlen 10 chars, no repetition of a name over different iterations of the alphabet) that we've built a bunch of tooling and practice around.

Suggestions inline for some clarifications.

(Looking back over the meeting log[*], Jeremy did say "i think it's also, separately, a good idea to continue with the currently published versioning plan to use release numbers as primary identifiers in our scheduling and automated processes, leaving the cycle names as more of a marketing feature which isn't integral to most of the schedule", but I'm not sure exactly what currently published versioning plan he was referring to.  I've only been on the TC a short while, so it may have happened before my time.)

A dumb question: do we keep the names for branches? Or we will have branch names like stable/2023_2 ?

I think I am mixing two things here, my bad. 

Till now, we concluded who will handle the release name and no objection to giving it to Foundation. but we still did not agree or even I will say discuss "Which one (release name or number) and how to use them in the development process". I will add the latter one to the TC meeting agenda with the release team or some ad-hoc meetings.

One thing clear is we need to make release numbers primary identifiers otherwise they will go unused.

There are a few options:

Option 1 (this proposal): Whether we want to keep the release name only for the marketing process. And only use the release number for the development process.

Option 2 (Current process): Use release names as it is they are used currently in the market as well as in the development process. Drop the release number as they might be just mentioned in this document and not used anywhere else.

Option 3 (new proposal): Use both release numbers as well names in the development process as well as on the marketing side. But the Primary identifier will be the release number. But might be complex to know where to use which one.

Release numbers we added earlier for the reason mentioned in L23. If we go with the 2nd approach then the question is how we will make use of numbers and people (develops as well as users) to remember this as the primary identifier of OpenStack releases. 

Option 1 will look like:

* Release schedule page:
  ** title: OpenStack 2023.1
  ** milestone as "2023.1-1 milestone"
* stable branches: stable/2023.1
* spec folder: specs/2023_1/approved

Option 3 will look like (or maybe any other better way but keep the release number as the primary identifier):
 
* Release schedule page:
  ** title: OpenStack 2023.1 (Aardvark) 
  ** milestone is ok to mention either "aardvark-1 milestone" or "2023.1-1 
     milestone". latter will be more aligned to use release number in the 
     development process.
* stable branches: stable/2023.1
* spec folder: specs/2023_1/approved or specs/aardvark/approved

opinion?

To be clear, the resolution was about the release identification -- clearly the release itself should be primarily identified as its number ("2023.1"). The question here is whether the *development cycle* should be primarily identified under the name ("the Aardvark development cycle") or the number. The release team finds 2023.1-2 and 2023.2-1 a lot less clear to communicate than Aardvark-2 and Brew-1, which is why it is our preference to communicate about development milestones using names. Stable branches are somewhere in the middle (created at the end of the cycle) -- we can make it work with names or numbers.

I suggest replacing lines 33-36 with "Each OpenStack development cycle has a code-name that is selected by the OpenDev Foundation following the process and criteria set out below.  As described in the "Release Identification" section above, this name is frequently used in combination with the version number to refer to the release at the end of the cycle."
This document needs to be update to reflect the above ^ as the current wording conflicts with that.

That's an excellent question... We discussed it during the release team meeting last Friday.

The release team will continue to use the name in development cycle names ("the Aardvark cycle") and release milestone names (think: "aardvark-1 milestone" instead of "2023.1-1 milestone"). In order to minimize release process changes, our preference would be to keep using the name in the branches as well (stable/aardvark rather than stable/2023.1)... But we could also make numbers work if that's a requirement for branch names.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Missing activity tracking Story/Task or launchpad number.

The title is supposed to have a verb (action). Its supposed to be a very brief statement of what this update is doing.

Something like ...

Delete platform backup partition if not meeting prestage requirement
Not clear what you are trying to say here.

... so that it will be recreated with the higher required size during the disk setup kickstart segment later in the kickstart execution.

I assume this to be true and if so would be valuable to add in the description for the reader.
actually, it should be "recreated with the default size of 30GB during ...". I will add this to the description.
default of 30G or a larger size as specified by persistent_size right ?

Not in the case of the prestage iso generated by gen-prestage-iso.sh. In this case, the default size is 30GB (fixed), and any partition size changes must be done during subcloud addition/upgrade at the system controller side using persistent_size parameter in the install_values.yaml file.
30G or greater because the platform backup partition is either created or deleted and recreated according to default or persistent_size right ?

When the subcloud is added (at the systemcontroller side, using dcmanager subcloud add subcloud<id>), and there is no persistent_size parameter in the install_values.yaml file, then the platform backup partition size is 30GB. However, if the user chooses to add a persistent_size parameter in the install_values.yaml file (example: persistent_size: 60000, for a 60GB partition size), then the size is appropriately increased to this number. The minimum is always 30GB.

In this particular case, I am referring to the partition size that was chosen *before* we installed the prestage ISO (as a result of a previous dcmanager subcloud add subcloud<id> operation on the SystemController).
Won't it pass because the platform backup partition is recreated to the specified size.

This is regression testing. If the force-install is not provided, and there is already an existing installation on the subcloud (as indicated by the presence of the install_uuid file at <mount_dir>/var/www/pages/feed/rel-xxxPLATFORM_RELEASExxx/ - mount_dir is where we have mounted /dev/${rootfs_device} ), then the expected behaviour is that the installation should fail.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
General Qs:

I guess I don't know the use case here. 

a) If we allow the backup partition to be bigger than 30G and it is, it was done for a reason. Will we avoid that reason now? Should we be eliminating the option to have a backup partition > 30G?

b) Are we only entering this code if and when we no longer care about what is currently preserved on backup partition? Do we need verify that the partition is empty before nuking it?

This is Subcloud Local Installation. We are not eliminating the option to have a backup > 30GB; it can always be configured (with persistent_size in an install_values.yaml file) when adding the subcloud with the dcmanager. In local installation, we use a prestaging iso which wipes off all the disks, re-creates the platform-backup partition, and then copies over a bootimage.iso to the platform-backup partition. This allows us to prestage the bootimage.iso.

We do not need to check that the partition is empty. If we have decided that we are going to use the prestage iso, then we will wipe out everything on the disk(s); unless there exists a valid subcloud installation already on the subcloud, in which case the prestage iso will NOT install (and thereby all disk contents will be preserved). Even so, we have a --force-install option in gen-prestage-iso.sh which will allow the prestage iso to overwrite the existing installation.
Seems fine by me. Not sure if you are going to address Kyle's latest comment. If not, can merge. Waiting on comment resolution.
will this impact the SX upgrade, during which the upgrade data (backup of N release) is stored in platform-backup?

This fix is only required if you decide to use Local Installation - i.e use the prestage iso (generated with gen-prestage-iso.sh) through a usb or redfish. If the decision to use this iso is made, then:
1.) If there is already an existing installation, then nothing will be lost. THe prestage iso will not install.
2.) Otherwise, if there is an existing installation but you used a force-install option, then everything will be lost.
3.) Or else, if there is no installation, then the platform-backup will be erased.

If you do NOT use the prestage iso, then there will not be any impact on SX upgrade.

kuryr_kubernetes/cni/handlers.py.message: What happens if node got rebooted? We should probably still re-plug the VIF, right? But that won't happen as the annotation is already set to "pluged". There's a typo BTW, this should be "plugged".

This is a bit worrying, there is a whitepaper published recently [1] that advises against DaemonSets having permissions to patch/update nodes. The point is that if someone executes container escape on a node, they can find such token and e.g. force node eviction until another pod being the target lands on compromised node. It would be good to find a way of doing that without these permissions. One would be to just have controller watch Nodes and create a CRD that'll hold the node's VIF and state.

[1] https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/resources/whitepapers/kubernetes-privilege-escalation-excessive-permissions-in-popular-platforms

Hi all,

I was going through the commits between iproute2-v5.10 and iproute2-v5.17 during the night connecting yesterday to today, and I came to the conclusion that this statement is inaccurate, because the "vrftable attribute in SRv6 End.DT4/DT6" feature requires kernel-side implementation that was introduced with Linux v5.11.y, so updating iproute2 will not be helpful.

I came to this conclusion as follows:

```
# iproute2 repository

$ git log -G SEG6_LOCAL_VRFTABLE include/uapi/linux/seg6_local.h 
commit cfad32569f67947110bcdb95da6956c0dbdcfc2d
Author: David Ahern <dsahern@gmail.com>
Date:   Wed Dec 9 02:25:34 2020 +0000

    Update kernel headers
    
    Update kernel headers to commit:
        afae3cc2da10 ("net: atheros: simplify the return expression of atl2_phy_setup_autoneg_adv()")
    
    Signed-off-by: David Ahern <dsahern@gmail.com>

# Get the corresponding iproute2 version out of curiosity only:
$ git describe --contains cfad32569f67947110bcdb95da6956c0dbdcfc2d
v5.11.0~32^2~7

# kernel repository

# Now, determine the kernel release corresponding to
# commit afae3cc2da10 in the kernel repository:
$ git describe --contains  afae3cc2da10
v5.11-rc1~169^2~87

# Corresponding commits in the kernel repository between
# v5.10 and v5.11:
$ git log --oneline -G SEG6_LOCAL_VRFTABLE v5.10..afae3cc2da10
20a081b7984c seg6: add VRF support for SRv6 End.DT6 behavior
664d6f86868b seg6: add support for the SRv6 End.DT4 behavior

# Modified files:
$ git show --oneline --name-only 664d6f86868b 20a081b7984c
664d6f86868b seg6: add support for the SRv6 End.DT4 behavior
include/uapi/linux/seg6_local.h
net/ipv6/seg6_local.c
20a081b7984c seg6: add VRF support for SRv6 End.DT6 behavior
net/ipv6/seg6_local.c

# Corresponding tags:
$ git describe --match='v5*' --contains 664d6f86868b 20a081b7984c
v5.11-rc1~169^2~121^2~3
v5.11-rc1~169^2~121^2~2
```

After having gone through the commits between iproute2-v5.10 and iproute2-v5.17 last night, I recall that most commits fall into the following categories:

* Some bug fixes, some of which fix issues going back in the distant past, and
* A number of code re-organizations, and
* A lot of kernel user-space API header updates and corresponding iproute2 changes and/or features, and finally,
* A number of new tools, such as "dcb" and "devlink" and "vdpa", which may or may not be relevant to StarlingX.

I did not spot a large number of important bug fixes that affect iproute2 v5.10 in Debian. The remarkable ones I recall are the following. (These do not appear to be present in Debian Bullseye's iproute2-v5.10.0-4.)

* 83d4d61bc90e libbpf: fix attach of prog with multiple sections (v5.14.0~22)
* a500c5ac8733 lib/bpf: fix map-in-map creation without prepopulation (v5.15.0~4)

All this to say, I started to think that I may have acted too eagerly when preparing this iproute2 uprevision commit, and I am wondering whether we really need to uprevision iproute2. My apologies in advance. I will attempt to get feedback from Mark.

(At the very least, I need to update the commit message so that it does not refer to the aforementioned feature introduced in the v5.11.y kernel.)

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Hi all,

I had a discussion with Mark today, and we thought that uprevisioning iproute2 would likely not provide a lot of benefit, because the kernel's version is v5.10.112, but the feature I had in mind for uprevisioning iproute2 was introduced with kernel v5.11. I will abandon this commit and its companion commit in a moment. I apologize for the unnecessary work.

Vefa

I don't think it is a great approach to verify a container as a member of an ensemble. A health of a container should not depend on external components. Otherwise it is impossible to say which is the failure container, if both API and MQ, or API or DB, or DB and MQ has seen as unhealthy. To properly assign alerts to clearly visible failure boundaries, each container must be checked as an independent unit. Perhaps the proposed approach better fits the liveness checks instead of healthchecks? If we'll have one day those under k8s management, we could get back to the ensemble-based checks.

It depends, really: if ppl use the oslo.middleware.healthcheck helper, there is a way to actually describe the issue - being a backend service being unreachable, or an actual API issue.

I'd rather avoid getting anything hitting directly backend services such as rabbitMQ, DB or DNS, since it would NOT represent the actual use - and, well, usually, for such services, in order to *check* them, it would require an actual connection with some action (a dumb "select" on a table, a DNS query, a sending and getting a message through the queue, and so on).

If we want to actually check/verify if an API is working, that API has to test its own dependencies - maybe the DB is up, but for #reason the user used by the API is deactivated/blocked/others.. How would you detect that? Same goes for DNS, it might work from one side, but the API needing the DNS might be blocked due to network issue, delays, and so on.

oh. Right, that "tiny" detail is missing from the spec: the goal is to NOT use the container engine native healthcheck, for multiple reasons (resources, for instance). I should make this clear, at the very top of the spec.

> If we want to actually check/verify if an API is working, that API has to test its own dependencies

debian_iso_image.inc.message:
It is usually good practice to not mix structural changes and actual changes as you really don't want to do this when submitting code to most open source projects. This is seen as a way to avoid debate. For example I assume you have done this to impose alphabetic order, which might be fine, but maybe a different ordering scheme would be better here but we don't know since there was no specific review to impose this, and thus no debate. Additionally the reviewers must split out what is related specifically to this change and what is not, easy in this case but not in all cases, it just becomes noise and distracts from the goal of the review.

If you care to do this, you need to split things in two. A commit to use alphabetic order first, then a second commit to add the iputils changes.

Hi Mark,

Thank you; good points. The trouble I am having is this:

For every change, StarlingX developers need a reason identifier (like a Closes-Bug tag or Story/Task tag pair) due to operational reasons. I do not know whether *most* open source projects have this requirement, but I would guess not.

This does not go well with one-off refactors or clean-up patches, because then reviewers rightfully point out that there is no reason identifier in the commit message, so these kinds of things stay unaddressed. This has been my point of view so far.

Now, I could open a bug on Launchpad or a task in a to-be-created clean-up story, but the friction introduced by this requirement is demotivating. Opening a bug on Launchpad is tedious due to the number of questions that need to be answered, and I am not aware of a general-improvements-should-go-in-this-story kind of story in the storyboard, so I am assuming that I would need to create one as well.

I will revert the ordering changes in this commit. It would be great if we could find a solution to the aforementioned difficulty, so that the code can be improved, in however minor ways, at least from my point of view.

Thank you.

"Opening a bug on Launchpad is tedious due to the number of questions that need to be answered"

Just ignore the template in those situations and just briefly state the nature of the cleanup work you want to do. eg. Alphabetically sort the blah list as was originally intended but not preserved by dumbasses making subsequent changes.

Yes the STX review tools definitely make this a bit burdensome. In a way this could be a feature and not a bug, in that if you care enough about a refactor you will go through the needed motions, and if the change is too minor, you will move on.

In this case I would have been fine with including a mention of the refactor in the commit log (I don't recall seeing anything related).

Anyway, thanks for making the update.

neutron/common/utils.py.message:
it looks like what this is checking is if the SessionTransaction has accumulated object changes that have been flushed.   It's true that if a flush has proceeded, that will indicate that the SessionTransaction is holding onto active connections.


However, if we are in fact interested in whether or not the SessionTransaction is actually holding onto checked-out database connections (which from a DBAPI point of view are therefore in a "tranasction"), you could simply look to see if it has any database connections, like this:


    if bool(session.transaction._connections):
        return True
    else:
        return False

now the above is a much more broad check -  a Session that was used just to emit some SELECT queries will report itself as "active" (which it is.  but i dont fully know what it is you want to determine here).

If, OTOH, you are only interested in a SessionTransaction where actual data changes (i.e. INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE) statements have proceeded, the previous check you have will **partially** work - it won't tell you if someone has run an UPDATE or DELETE outside of the unit of work, such as if someone said session.query(Model).update(), which it's very likely that Neutron makes use of somewhere.

So testing for "_connections" is definitely the more broad-based, "do we have any database resources in play" test and it might be better if you can make that work for you.


Overall the biggest problem is that neutron really shouldn't have cases where it even needs to know if the session has active changes or not, it would ideally organize its operations such that if an operation needs to proceed with no transaction to start with, then no transaction is started in the first place; that is, it shouldn't be asking questions about what other parts of the code might have done.   This is obviously a longer term architectural thing though.

I'll start with the last comment. I agree with you: Neutron should not check this status. The code should have been implemented in a way that we don't need to check the status of the DB session (or transaction). But there are some bits of the code implemented when nested transaction where allowed and other sections use this check to protect from modifying the DB during another operation transaction.

You are right on the fact that checking the connections is a more broad check. But in this case is a valid check and better that checking of there is any pending operation. Read (SELECT) operations do not increase any "new", "dirty" or "deleted" counters. I'll use it instead.

In any case, I'll review all Neutron uses of this method in order to refactor the code and avoid it.

If project has the solution to those then it is ok for heat to keep it but we need to note that it will be only heat direct dependency and not indirect deps as other OpenStack projects dropping it for same reason (2nd point in resolution).

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: I've no experience with xstatic packaging & versioning. Nevertheless, it looks OK to me, I have only one question inline.

deliverables/_independent/xstatic-angula.message:
nit: As I understand Xstatic codes are delivered with the exact same version number as the original package (AngularJS 1.8.2 this time). The last number should be the incremented build number I guess. But....

* 1.8.2.0 had a build number (in xstatic/pkg/angular/__init__.py) '1', still the version had 0 as last number
* now we have a build number (in ^^^ __init__.py) '2'. do we want to release it as 1.8.2.2 based on that? why not just increment.

This project is not often released so I don't really remember the previous releases.

The proposed version LGTM is seems aligned with the version targeted in the init file:
- https://opendev.org/openstack/xstatic-angular/src/branch/master/xstatic/pkg/angular/__init__.py#L14
- https://opendev.org/openstack/xstatic-angular/src/branch/master/xstatic/pkg/angular/__init__.py#L16

Please refer to https://opendev.org/openstack/xstatic-angular/commit/375ee8e424d913b3759b67e9263a38a56c84942c
Ok, thanks for the answer. then this LGTM.
Thanks for all the details Akihiro! Nice insight to the history of the build numbers here :)
The build number just has to increase. As long as it is monotonic, it doesn't matter what the value is.

I have follow-up commnets.

In general, the build number (4th digit in the version number) in the release should match BUILD in xstatic/pkg/angular/__init__.py. The build number usually starts from 0.

However, when we prepared Angular 1.8.2, BUILD number in xstatic/pkg/angular/__init__.py started with 1 by mistake. In addition, we cut a PyPI release as 1.8.2.0. (It had to be 1.8.2.1 if BUILD = 1).

I updated the contents of xstatic-angular with the upstream recently. The contents published by the upstream have been changed a bit (still with the same version number 1.8.2). There is a change in the contents, so we must increase the build number at least.

Considering this, I recommeneded to use a new build number we did not use before, so the build number 2 is used now.

This name is a bit confusing since we're actually passing in a string representation of a key/value tuple.

just to point out possible problems with the logic, it is legal to specify "hugepages=" by itself as long as "default_hugepagesz" is specified, in which case it will allocate that many pages of the default size.

But if we always specify a pagesize and count as pairs then we won't run into any problems.
just as a heads-up, it is legal to specify "foo=" in the kernel boot args, this corresponds to an environment variable for the init task.

If  "foo=" in the kernel boot args, it will be parsed as key='foo', val=''
>>> param = 'foo='
>>> param.split('=')
['foo', '']
typically this would go up at the top.  And I think "conf_file" would be clearer.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Kinda need a better reason than this. Rationale should be: 

Under CentOS, the initscripts package provides the upstream /etc/sysctl.conf. initscripts-config installs a custom /etc/sysctl.conf and monitor-tools updates /etc/sysctl.conf in a scriptlet. Under Debian, /etc/sysctl.conf is provided by the procps package so there is no need for either of these packages to be dependent on initscripts nor should we include initscripts or its dependents in the ISO.

So I like the general idea behind the patch, but before we merge this: do we really want to use "-1" as the special value?

I would have used "0" since no one would actually want to delete 0 row. It also feels a bit more "natural" to me, and easier to type for admins :) Do we have other commands in Glance/OpenStack that reuse an "invalid" value to mean "no limits"? If so, do they use 0 or -1?

IMHO it's more natural to use "None" for variables which have not value.
But we discussed it already and everyone was happy with "-1".
IMHO "0" means 0 rows and it does not look like valid value for no limit.
Also admin can use value "0" in order just to check if the script can be launched but admin doesn't want to purge rows.
